abstract.textEnglish: A new instrument was designed to take visible-light (VL) polarized brightness ( <inline-formula id="IEq1"> <mml:math> <mml:mi mathvariant="italic">pB</mml:mi> </mml:math> </inline-formula>) observations of the solar corona during the 14 December 2020 total solar eclipse. The instrument, called the Coronal Imaging Polarizer (CIP), consisted of a 16 MP CMOS detector, a linear polarizer housed within a piezoelectric rotation mount, and an f-5.6, 200 mm DSLR lens. Observations were successfully obtained, despite poor weather conditions, for five different exposure times (0.001 s, 0.01 s, 0.1 s, 1 s, and 3 s) at six different orientation angles of the linear polarizer ( <inline-formula id="IEq2"> <mml:math> <mml:msup> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>∘</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:math> </inline-formula>, <inline-formula id="IEq3"> <mml:math> <mml:msup> <mml:mn>30</mml:mn> <mml:mo>∘</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:math> </inline-formula>, <inline-formula id="IEq4"> <mml:math> <mml:msup> <mml:mn>60</mml:mn> <mml:mo>∘</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:math> </inline-formula>, <inline-formula id="IEq5"> <mml:math> <mml:msup> <mml:mn>90</mml:mn> <mml:mo>∘</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:math> </inline-formula>, <inline-formula id="IEq6"> <mml:math> <mml:msup> <mml:mn>120</mml:mn> <mml:mo>∘</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:math> </inline-formula>, and <inline-formula id="IEq7"> <mml:math> <mml:msup> <mml:mn>150</mml:mn> <mml:mo>∘</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:math> </inline-formula>). The images were manually aligned using the drift of background stars in the sky and images of different exposure times were combined using a simple signal-to-noise ratio cut. The polarization and brightness of the local sky were also estimated and the observations were subsequently corrected. The <inline-formula id="IEq8"> <mml:math> <mml:mi mathvariant="italic">pB</mml:mi> </mml:math> </inline-formula> of the K-corona was determined using least-squares fitting and radiometric calibration was done relative to the Mauna Loa Solar Observatory (MLSO) K-Cor <inline-formula id="IEq9"> <mml:math> <mml:mi mathvariant="italic">pB</mml:mi> </mml:math> </inline-formula> observations from the day of the eclipse. The <inline-formula id="IEq10"> <mml:math> <mml:mi mathvariant="italic">pB</mml:mi> </mml:math> </inline-formula> data was then inverted to acquire the coronal electron density, <inline-formula id="IEq11"> <mml:math> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mi>e</mml:mi> </mml:msub> </mml:math> </inline-formula>, for an equatorial streamer and a polar coronal hole, which agreed very well with previous studies. The effect of changing the number of polarizer angles used to compute the <inline-formula id="IEq12"> <mml:math> <mml:mi mathvariant="italic">pB</mml:mi> </mml:math> </inline-formula> is also discussed and it is found that the results vary by up to <inline-formula id="IEq13"> <mml:math> <mml:mo>≈</mml:mo> <mml:mn>13</mml:mn> <mml:mi mathvariant="normal">%</mml:mi> </mml:math> </inline-formula> when using all six polarizer angles versus only a select of three angles.
